title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with African-Americans being overrepresented in executions and on death row. No state meets ABA standards for indigent prisoners' legal representation. The House Judiciary Subcommittee found that 89% of defendants selected for capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 were African-American or Hispanic American. The General Accounting Office reported racial disparities in charging, sentencing, and imposition of the death penalty in 1990. Prisoner appeals have been limited, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent people. The Supreme Court has restricted death row prisoners' rights to appeal convictions and death sentences in Federal courts, even with compelling evidence of innocence. New legislation in 1996 further limited Federal court appeals. In 1996, new legislation restricted Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners. The Federal and State death penalty is currently on hold until Congress reviews the final findings and recommendations of the National Commission on the Death Penalty. This moratorium will continue until legislation is enacted based on the Commission's guidelines and procedures. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with relevant expertise. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President, including individuals from various backgrounds such as government, academia, nonprofit organizations, and industry. The President must ensure a balanced membership with differing opinions on the death penalty. Initial appointments should be made within 30 days of enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission with vacancies filled promptly. The National Commission on the Death Penalty, established with 15 members appointed by the President from diverse backgrounds, operates with specific guidelines. Vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled promptly. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all initial members being appointed, with meetings called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the President designates a Chair. Rules and procedures govern the Commission's proceedings. The National Commission on the Death Penalty, established with 15 members appointed by the President from diverse backgrounds, operates with specific guidelines. Vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled promptly. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all initial members being appointed, with meetings called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the President designates a Chair. Rules and procedures govern the Commission's proceedings. SEC. 202. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The National Commission on the Death Penalty, established with 15 members appointed by the President, conducts a study on matters related to the administration of the death penalty to ensure constitutional principles and fairness. This includes examining racial disparities, disproportionality based on geographic location and income, and adequacy of representation for capital defendants. The National Commission on the Death Penalty, established to study the administration of the death penalty, focuses on various issues such as the competency of counsel in capital cases, wrongful convictions, federal government seeking death penalty in states without it, independent judgment in constitutional claims, sentencing mentally retarded and juvenile offenders to death, and ensuring access to forensic evidence for persons sentenced to death. The National Commission on the Death Penalty aims to establish guidelines and procedures to ensure fair and impartial administration of the death penalty, minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals, and prevent racial discrimination in its application. A preliminary report is due within one year of the Act's enactment. The National Commission on the Death Penalty will submit a preliminary report within one year of the Act's enactment, followed by a final report with detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations within two years. SEC. 203. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the power to obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as necessary for carrying out its provisions. The Commission has the authority to request records, correspondence, memoranda, and materials deemed necessary. Subpoenas issued must be signed by the Chairperson and enforced by the district court in case of non-compliance. Testimony of individuals in custody can be obtained within the jurisdiction of the court. The Commission can request necessary records and materials, issue subpoenas signed by the Chairperson, and obtain testimony from individuals in custody within the court's jurisdiction. The Attorney General can request a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to produce a person before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees will be paid from Commission funds according to section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and necessary staff without following civil service laws, and set their compensation. The Commission can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws, with pay not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. It can spend up to $850,000 for its operations, funded by the Department of Justice.
